lines.text: Andy, I've this one dead to rights! Otis was drunk. I even gave him a test. I drew a line on the sidewalk and told him to walk it. You know what he said?
What?
He asked me what line. I've got this one right, Andy. Otis was drunk!
That right, Otis? Did you ask Deputy Fife what line?
Yeah; but I didn't have my specs on and drunk or sober, I can't see much without my specs.
Otis, three hours ago when Deputy Fife arrested you were you drunk?
I don't know; I wasn't wearin' my glasses.
Boy, giraffes are selfish.
Well, I guess to sum it up, you could say, there's three reasons why there's so little crime in Mayberry. There's Andy, and there's me, and
[patting gun]
baby makes three.
What's the matter, haven't you ever seen a man take off a dress before?
[Andy has told Rafe Hollister to try out for the musical]
I'm surprised at you, Andy. They want people who have had musical training. Why, suppose they ask Rafe to do something he don't know? Rafe, if they asked you to sing a cappella, could you do it?
No.
Hey, Barn, what if they was to ask you if you could sing a cappella, what would *you* do?
Why, I'd do it!
[snapping fingers in rhythm]
"A cappella, a cappella"... Well, I don't remember all the words.

[find Aunt Bee obviously "tiddly", then finding a 2/3 empty bottle of "Colonel Harvey's Elixir" in the hall closet]
Well, it sure looks like she took the adult dose.
What are you doing?
Gun-drawing practice, ten minutes every day. If I ever have to use this baby, I want to teach it to come to papa in a hurry.
Dud, did you tell Ernest T. Bass the Sheriff wanted to see him?
I couldn't find him, Mr. Darlin'. His cousin said he went into the woods to kill a mockingbird.
He doesn't sound like a very nice person.
One of the worst we got.
I'm a little mean, but I make up for it by bein' real healthy. Say you'll be mine. Say you'll be my beloved!
Adios, amigo.

[to Andy]
He one of ours?
Oh, sure.

[to Barney]
More power to ya.

[Aunt Bee has hit Briscoe with a spoon]
Ow! What'd you do that for?
No elbows on the table.

[to Andy]
That ain't fair; her hittin' first and explainin' the rules after.

[Picking up the phone]
Sarah? What? Just soak it. That's right; just soak it a lot in warm water. Listen, Sarah; get me Thelma Lou. I know she's Barney's girl; just get her on the phone. What? 'Cause I don't want to. No, Sarah, I wouldn't rather talk to Juanita at the diner; just get Thelma Lou.
It rained last week, ya know?
Yeah... yeah... I was right there in it.

You date one woman all the time and pretty soon people start taking you for granted. They don't say, "Let's invite Andy," or "Let's invite Elly." No, they say. "Let's invite Andy and Elly!" See, then it's "Andy and Elly"; "Elly and Andy". A then, that's when that woman gets her claws into you!

[reading a note tied to a rock Ernest T. Bass threw through the window]
"Maybe you goin' to have a weddin', and maybe you goin' to have a preacher; but you might not have a bride. You ever think of that?" Mr. Darling, you don't think he'd try to kidnap Charlene before the wedding?
He might. He's just crazy enough to do it.
Well, you just let him try! I'll show him some things I learned in the army in jungle warfare! First, you grab the mouth and pull like this.
[demonstrates by pulling his own mouth]
Then you grade his nose and twist it like this.
[twists his own nose]
Stop that, boy! You want your face to freeze thatta' way?
If there's anything that upsets me, it's having people say I'm sensitive.

[about Briscoe's decision not to kill Ernest T]
It's a wise man who knows not to push the limits of the law.

[to Andy]
He arguin' with me?
No; he's agreein' with you.
Just so I know where I stand.
Where's my 'darlin' person'? There she is!
[grabs Charlene and begins hugging and kissing her]
Dud! Stop it!
Aw. c'mon Charlene!
Stop that, boy! We got other things to do. Try to control them hot flashes.

[Andy and Barney are watching a sign painter]
Ain't he got chicken spelled wrong?
No, it's right.
You sure?
Yeah, it's "i before e except after c and e before n in chicken".

[chuckles]
Oh yeah, I always forget that rule.
[the Darlings are discussing the song they are going to play at Charlene's wedding]
How 'bout "Don't Hit Your Grandma with a Great Big Stick"?
No, Paw, That one makes me cry!

[Briscoe is getting dressed for Charlene's wedding]
Hold still, Mr. Darling, while I put on your tie.
Ever since I saw a hangin', I been nervous about wearin' one of these things.
Well, I caught him earlier on a 10-17.
Hat in a horse trough?
Yeah.
[Gomer has made a citizens arrest on Barney]
All right, what's goin' on here?
Aw this boob here...
Boob? Why that's an insult in the face of the public!
[after writing himself a traffic ticket]
A boob that's what I am, a boob!
[Goober thinks he has whiplash]
Floyd made the diagnosis.
Floyd, what do you know about whiplash?
What do you mean? A barber does a lot of work around the back of the neck.
[Opie has a crush on Thelma Lou]
Pa, just what can you do with a grown woman?
Gomer, get down there with them spiders and start workin'!

[on the phone]
If you don't want magazine subscriptions or your septic tank pumped out, there's a sign you can get that says no peddlers or agents.
[pause]
Well, sure that applies to septic tank pumpers... sure. Now take down those disease signs, Nelvin.
I love picnics. Speaking of picnics, you remember that movie 'Picnic'? Cary Grant sure was good it that movie.
Goober, Cary Grant wasn't in 'Picnic'.
He wasn't? Well, speakin' of Cary Grant, I do him.
What?
I take off on Cary Grant. Want to hear me do Cary Grant?
Uh, Goober...
Be glad to. Judy. Judy. Judy.
That's real good, Goober; but Cary Grant wasn't in 'Picnic'.
That was William Holden.
William Holden? Heck, I can't do William Holden; he sounds like everybody else.
[Andy and Helen walk off with Goober following]
I can't do William Holden, but I can do Cary Grant. Judy. Judy. Judy.

[Barney and Thelma Lou have had a fight on the phone]
Uh, Barn; why don't you just call her back?

[Picking up the phone]
Sarah, get me Juanita at the diner. No, I wouldn't just rather call Thelma Lou back!
Barney, you can't give Otis a sobriety test now; he's had all night to sleep it off. The time to give him a sobriety test was last night when you picked him up.
I couldn't give him the test last night!
Why?
He was too drunk.

[to Andy]
Well, if it ain't daddy long legs!

[while relaxing on the front porch after Sunday dinner]
You know what I think I'm gonna' do?
What?
I'm gonna' go home, have me a little nap, and then go over to Thelma Lou's and watch a little TV.
Mmm-hmm.
Yeah, I believe that's what I'll do. Go home... have a nap... and then over to Thelma Lou's for TV.
Mmm.
Yep, that's the plan. Home... little nap... then...

[interrupting]
For the love of Mike *do* it!
[shouts]
Do it! Just *do* it! Go take a nap, go to Thelma Lou's for TV, just *do it*!

[to Emmett]
You blew it. You stood right there and blew it.
That's the clunker we sold to that boob in Mayberry.

[serenading Aunt Bee]
Low and lonely, sad and blue / Thinking only, of little you / Always tryin', to keep from cryin' / I'm low and lonely over you.
Goob, did anybody ever tell you you've got a big mouth?
Yeah, but I don't pay no attention to 'em.
[after a haircut at Floyd's]
Floyd.
What's the matter?
My sideburns.
Your sideburns - what's the matter with your sideburns?
Why, they're both even.
Well, I'll be dogged. How'd that happen?
I declare, Floyd, I believe you're getting the hang of it. And looka there - they're the right length and everything.
[after getting in a fight with Andy]
Just who do you think you are, anyway, Mayberry's answer to Cary Grant?
Let her go off somewhere else... gig some other frog.

[after learning Barney has spilled the beans about the gold shipment]
Somewhere between here and Denver is seven million dollars headed for Mayberry, and you and me and Gomer and Laura Lee Hobbs, we're gonna' receive it.
If a duck stood still you could catch him by the bill.
Opie! Time to come in, son.
Aw Pa, just a little while longer... please?
Well, OK.
[to Barney]
Daylight's precious when your a youngen'.

[while looking at himself in the mirror]
Wretch, wretch! Deceitful wretch!
[Andy and Barney are at the Darlings when a rock comes through the window]
What was that!
I think Ernest T. Bass is paying us another visit.
Ernest T. Bass! You're a low down skunk!
[Turns away from the window, then turns back]
Doggone ya!
Listen here, Ernest T. Bass! This is Sheriff Taylor! Go on home and leave these people alone! You're keepin' 'em awake!
Tell 'em to go back to bed! Charlene's the one I want to talk to!
Listen here, Ernest T. Bass! This is Deputy Fife! I'm armed and if you don't go home, I might just take a shot at you
[another rock come flying through the window]
Stop that!
[Another rock hits the window]
Sheriff, tell your deputy to be quiet before he gets us all stoned to death!
[Ernest T. Bass has crashed Mrs. Wily's party]
He burst into the house uninvited and started behaving in the most peculiar manner.
Like what, Mrs. Wily?
Oh, he stuck his hand in the punch bowl and ate every bit of the watermelon rind. And if that wasn't enough, he soaked the paper napkins in the punch and then he threw them at the ceiling.
Didn't anybody try to stop him?
Mr. Schwump tried to pinch him, but he just giggled and jumped away.
I'll say it right to your face, Otis, you've got a pickled liver!
Well, it's better than having a pickled puss!
Oh, yeah?
Yeah!
Boys, stop it!
Well, he started it!
I did not start it, he started it!

[through a megaphone while directing the cave rescue]
Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their neighbor! Repeat! Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their neighbor!

[telling Opie and his friends the story of Paul Revere]
And he said, "The British is comin, the British is comin! Git your guns, we gonna have us a revolution!"
I don't chew my cabbage twice. And you ain't heard the last of Ernest T. Bass!
Inkem binkem notamus rex, protect us all from the man with the hex.
Fly away buzzard, fly away crow, way down south where the winds don't blow. Rub your nose and give two winks and save us from this awful jinx.
Where can we find this Ernest T. Bass?
Aww, he's a pestilence and a pestilence will find *you*... you just wait.
If I keep this up I'll probably end up with a barber's claw from holding the shears all day.
